contentrichtext.text: {{other places|King John's Castle}} [[File:King John's Castle in Limerick.jpg|thumb|King John's Castle in 2007.]] [[File:LimerickCity KingJohnsCastle 2010.jpeg|thumb|King John's Castle on the River Shannon.]] [[File:King John's Castle in Limerick (1).jpg|thumb|Castle Courtyard]] '''King John's Castle''' is a castle located on [[King's Island, Limerick|King's Island]] in [[Limerick]], [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]], next to the [[River Shannon]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.shannonheritage.com/Attractions/KingJohnsCastle/ | title=King John's Castle | publisher=[http://www.shannonheritage.com/ Shannon Heritage] | accessdate=June 30, 2011}}</ref> The walls, towers and fortifications remain today, and are a visitor attraction. The remains of a [[Viking]] settlement were uncovered during the construction of a visitor centre at the site. The [[Viking]] sea-king, Thormodr Helgason, built the first permanent Viking stronghold on Inis Sibhtonn ([[King's Island, Limerick|King's Island]]) in 922. He used the base to raid the length of the [[River Shannon]] from [[Lough Derg (Shannon)|Lough Derg]] to [[Lough Ree]], pillaging ecclesiastical settlements. In 937 the Limerick Vikings clashed with those of [[Dublin]] on Lough Ree and were defeated. In 943 they were defeated again when the chief of the local Dalcassian clan joined with Ceallachán, king of [[Munster]] and the Limerick Vikings were forced to pay tribute to the clans. The power of the Vikings never recovered, and they were reduced to the level of a minor clan, however often playing pivotal parts in the endless power struggles of the next few centuries. The arrival of the Anglo-Normans to the area in 1172 changed everything. [[Domnall Mór Ua Briain|Domhnall Mór Ó Briain]] burned the city to the ground in 1174 in a bid to keep it from the hands of the new invaders. After he died in 1194, the Anglo-Normans finally captured the area in 1195, under [[John of England|John]], [[Lord of Ireland]]. In 1197, local legend claims Limerick was given its first [[City Charter|charter]] and its first Mayor, Adam Sarvant. A castle, built on the orders of King John and bearing his name, was completed around 1200. Under the general peace imposed by the Norman rule, Limerick prospered as a port and trading centre. By this time the city was divided into an area became known as "English Town" on King's Island, while another settlement, named "Irish Town" had grown on the south bank of the river. A 1574 document prepared for the Spanish ambassador attests to its wealth: :''Limerick is stronger and more beautiful than all the other cities of Ireland, well walled with stout walls of hewn marble... There is no entrance except by stone bridges, one of the two of which has 14 arches, and the other 8 ... for the most part the houses are of square stone of black marble and built in the form of towers and fortresses.''{{citation needed|date=June 2011}} The walls of the castle were severely damaged in the [[Siege of Limerick 1642]], the first of five sieges of the city in the 17th century. In 1642, the castle was occupied by Protestants fleeing the [[Irish Rebellion of 1641]] and was besieged by an Irish Confederate force under [[Garret Barry (soldier)|Garret Barry]]. Barry had no siege artillery so he undermined the walls of King John's Castle by digging away their foundations. Those inside surrendered just before Barry collapsed the walls. However, such was the damage done to the wall's foundations that a section of them had to be pulled down afterward. ==See also== *[[John of England|King John of England]] *[[History of Limerick|History of Limerick City]] *[[Limerick City Museum]], just to the south ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|King John's Castle (Limerick)}} * [http://www.shannonheritage.com/Attractions/KingJohnsCastle/ Shannon Heritage site] {{Limerick}} {{Historic Irish houses}} {{coord|52|40|11|N|8|37|32|W|region:IE_type:landmark|display=title}} [[Category:Museums with year of establishment missing]] [[Category:Castles in County Limerick]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Limerick (city)]] [[Category:National Monuments in County Limerick]] [[Category:Historic house museums in the Republic of Ireland]] [[Category:Museums in County Limerick]] [[Category:Military and war museums in the Republic of Ireland]] [[Category:John, King of England]]
